newsitem.title: PAKISTAN: Pakistan pleads for peace with India after clash.
newsitem.headline: Pakistan pleads for peace with India after clash.

text.p: Pakistani Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif pleaded for peace with India on Wednesday after a border clash between the two arch-rivals in which a Pakistan army major was killed.
In a televised address, Sharif urged his nation to consider what had been gained from 50 years' hostility between the two nations since independence, and suggested it was time to try "other means".
"In the past 50 years we fought wars and our relations have been strained," he said. "Is there no lesson for the two countries in the 50 years' history?"
Sharif made his conciliatory remarks hours after a Pakistani military statement said a major in a paramilitary force was killed in an overnight cross-border clash in the eastern Sialkot sector.
It said the Indian Border Security Force (BSF), firing from the Indian-ruled part of the disputed Kashmir region, also suffered casualties but their number was not known.
It was the most serious border clash for several months between the two countries, currently preparing for a second round in recently-resumed peace talks.

Sharif said he had proposed to Indian Prime Minister Inder Kumar Gujral "why not to try other means" instead of hostility, and that the two sides negotiate on all issues, including their dispute over Kashmir. The two leaders met during a South Asian summit conference in Male, capital of the Maldives, last month.
"The Indian prime minister's response to this was positive, (and) he also agreed with the proposal to follow the path of negotiations," Sharif said.
India rules two-thirds and Pakistan the rest of Kashmir, over which the two countries have fought two of their three wars since independence from Britain in 1947.
Sharif said India-Pakistan relations could be productive only "when Kashmiris' right to self-determination" was accepted. "This is the basic point, by agreeing on which we can proceed further."

New Delhi regards the whole of Kashmir as an integral part of India, but Islamabad wants the predominantly Moslem Kashmiris to decide in a U.N.-mandated plebiscite whether to join Islamic Pakistan or Hindu-majority India.

The Pakistani statement earlier said the border clash followed "unprovoked firing" by the Indian BSF on civilians building an embankment on the Pakistani side of what it called the working boundary with the Indian-ruled part of Kashmir.
"Pakistan (paramilitary) Rangers personnel moved in support of the civilians and, during exchange of fire, Major Jamil of Pakistan Rangers embraced Shahadat (martyrdom)," it said.
"Pakistan Rangers retaliated, inflicting casualties on the BSF," the statement said. "However, the number of Indian casualties could not be ascertained."
Tension has run high between the two sides during more than seven years of a separatist revolt in Indian Kashmir.
Top Indian and Pakistani foreign ministry officials met in New Delhi in March, marking a resumption of the dialogue between the two countries after a three-year deadlock over Kashmir.
Pakistan has proposed the next round in Islamabad be held on June 19-22, but still awaits Indian approval of the dates.
